Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Fire: Productive Disciplinary Engagement in a Complex Virtual Engineering Task; Authenticity, Rolls, and Activity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This collaborative proposal brings together engineering education researchers from one institution (Oregon State University) and learning scientists from another (University of Washington) in a two-year project involving two studies designed to investigate how productive disciplinary engagement is supported and constrained in a collaborative virtual engineering task in a capstone course. In one study, sociocultural and affective frames will be brought to bear on extant data (already analyzed cognitively) in order to explore interactions within five student groups working on the task, and between groups and instructor. These secondary analyses will focus on patterns of engagement, discourse processes, and social context of the groups embedded in the larger context of the course with the aim of shedding light on the ways in which engagement and learning develop. The second study will entail analyses of primary data (collected via pre- and post- surveys of students in the capstone course) to investigate the relationship of the experience in the virtual laboratory groups and student learning, interest in engineering, and post-graduate plans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was aimed at building capacity for engineering education through the collaboration of an engineer (Koretsky) and a learning scientist (Nolen). Through collaborative research, the two investigators deepened their knowledge of each others’ disciplines and contributed to the knowledge base in engineering education and STEM education more broadly.

The researchers studied factors supporting the productive disciplinary engagement and collaboration of teams of expert and student engineers by analyzing their interactions during design tasks. They also compared the extent to which virtual and physical engineering laboratories supported disciplinary thinking (modeling) and engagement. The findings extend previous work on disciplinary engagement in science, which has primarily focused on students learning to interpret data and build evidence-based arguments, to design tasks in engineering and environmental science. This research has led to new understandings about the nature of design work, both in terms of thinking and the social interaction skills needed for productive collaboration. We have also identified aspects of “school” learning that may interfere with development of design thinking, as well as aspects of more realistic contexts that facilitate it. This knowledge has led to recommendations for designing more effective learning systems that will allow educators to better prepare students for the workforce.

These results are significant in several ways. First, they have made clear the ways in which productive disciplinary engagement can be supported by design tasks in both engineering and in environmental science, and related designers’ levels of expertise to the ways they think about design. We have compared physical and virtual modes of data collection on students’ engineering disciplinary practices and their resulting engagement. Among several contexts, we have related disciplinary engagement to metacognitive regulation for both higher and lower performing teams. Finally, we have characterized very different responses to uncertainty between expert and student teams and related them to their affective and cognitive responses. These results are communicated through four manuscripts in review or preparation. Development of engineering practice (including developing skills for effective collaboration) is an increasing focus of the field of engineering education. This research will likely have an impact on both instruction and theory.

The project has facilitated collaboration among researchers from three countries (Finland, US, Australia) and is supporting the ongoing development of frameworks for studying productive disciplinary engagement (PDE) in STEM education settings. What we have learned by studying the interactions of STEM students across specific disciplines with the same analytical framework, researchers, and coding schemes is helping to refine the concept of PDE and extending it to contexts beyond K-12 mathematics (in which it was originally developed by Engle & Conant), and to uncover context-specific differences in the way PDE manifests across levels and disciplines.
